awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a meter-class telescope at Western Kentucky University
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigators propose to replace an out of date telescope and control system used at Western Kentucky University (WKU) with a modern telescope and control system.  The new instrument will provide students and faculty at WKU and nearby colleges and universities, a platform with which they can undertake research-quality observations.  The instrument will be used by students and faculty to study a range of research involving studies of distant galaxies and outstanding questions in stellar astronomy.  The new instrument will enable WKU to increase the involvement of undergraduate students in research projects.  

The investigators propose to replace the existing 40-year-old, 0.6 m Group 128 telescope and control system at Western Kentucky University’s (WKU) Bell Observatory with a new PlaneWave 0.7 m telescope and control system.  This new instrument will serve students and faculty at WKU and nearby colleges and universities.  There is currently no instrument in the state that is both large enough to provide research quality data and widely available to students and faculty.  The instrument will be used by researchers  (1) to understand the structure of, and emission mechanisms at work in, Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN); (2) to probe the structure of the Milky Way galaxy; (3) to distinguish between transiting planetary systems and low mass eclipsing binaries; and (4) to study previously neglected classes of variable stars that are important distance indicators (RR Lyrae variables) and systems that allow the direct determination of physical characteristics of stars (eclipsing binary stars).  

This project is jointly funded by the AST ATI Program, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and OD/OIA/MRI.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main project outcome was the successful installation and subsequent routine operation of an 1.0-meter class telescope at Western Kentucky University's (WKU) Bell Observatory. A PlaneWave CDK 700 telescope was installed and is  operational at the Bell observatory.  The system is capable of local, remote and unattended operations. In addition to the telescope and control software, it includes an existing  CCD camera, new broad and narrow band filters, upgraded dome automation hardware and software, LED calibration screen, and cameras for both system monitoring during remote operations and to evaluate sky conditions in real time. An advantage of the CDK 700 is that it has two different observing ports. The second port contains a repurposed low resolution spectrograph, which further enhances the system's capabilities. 

This system replaced the 40 + year old existing system which had exceeded its life expectancy and its ability to be maintained and upgraded.Research active astronomers are found at all of the state and many of the private institutions of higher education in Kentucky and along its border, regardless of whether they are research, regional comprehensive or teaching institutions. Despite the presence of active research astronomers in Kentucky, no meter-class or larger telescope is locally available to all researchers within Kentucky.  This project addressed that need and provides facilities to enhance undergraduate education not only at WKU, but across Kentucky and its  border regions. Eight research projects led by faculty and students from 5 different Kentucky universities are either planned or implemented on the system. These projects will expand our understanding of supermassive black holes, pulsating and other types of variable stars, and the structure of the galaxy.

Students and faculty from across Kentucky can access the facility and be trained to use it either locally or remotely from their home institutions.Four WKU students have been trained as telescope observers, along with an undergraduate student from the University of Kentucky. One UK undergraduate student and two WKU undergraduate students have obtained data for thier research projects with the system. In addition to supporting independent research projects, the system is also available for use by students in introductory and advanced astronomy classes for laboratory exercises and class projects.The system has already supported introductory astronomy classes at the University of Louisville and advanced astronomy classes at WKU.

In addition to the optical telecope system, a 3-meter student run radio telescope is also being constructed.The WKU radio telescope project is converting an old home satellite TV receiving system, designed only to point at fixed sky positions, into a fully steerable scientific instrument with modern, state-of-the-art receivers.  The 10-foot (3-meter) dish will be able to acquire and track any object in the sky using a rugged, custom-designed altitude-azimuth mount, with both axes managed by a special control interface that includes feedback from position encoders and limit switches to ensure safe and reliable operations.  Receivers covering three different frequency bands and software-defined radio devices will allow the detection and study of radio emissions from many heavenly bodies in our solar system, across the galaxy, and beyond.  Control and data access will be through a wired network connection.  Added safety and security will be provided by remote cameras.

Project goals include: (1) fostering collaboration between the WKU physics, astronomy, and engineering programs to design and build the telescope; (2) giving students in these programs hands-on technical experience as part of this process; (3) augmenting student education and career training via direct operations of the telescope and analysis of its observations and live classroom demonstrations; (4) enriching public education and outreach to school groups and the broader community through demonstration of the ``invisible universe'' revealed by radio waves, plus added WKU student training in science education; and (5) raising the public profile of WKU through service to its students and the region while also providing a radio facility for partner educational institutions throughout Kentucky.  To date, over 51 WKU students, 17 faculty and staff, and 6 external advisors have been involved in fulfilling the first two goals, with broader impacts for the other goals anticipated in the near future.
